sen.j: 高山寺（こうざんじ）は、京都市右京区梅ヶ畑栂尾（とがのお）町にある寺院。
sen.e: Kozan-ji Temple is a Buddhist temple situated in Toganoo Cho, Umegahata, Ukyo Ward, Kyoto City.
Kozan-ji Temple is a Buddhist temple situated in Toganoo Cho, Umegahata, Ukyo Ward, Kyoto City.
Kozan-ji Temple is a Buddhist temple situated in Toganoo-cho, Umegahata, Ukyo Ward, Kyoto City.

sen.j: 栂尾は京都市街北西の山中に位置する。
sen.e: Toganoo is located in the mountains to the northwest of the city of Kyoto.
Toganoo is located in the mountains to the northwest of the city of Kyoto.
Toganoo is located in the mountains to the northwest of the city of Kyoto.

sen.j: 高山寺は山号を栂尾山と称し、宗派は真言宗御室派系の単立である。
sen.e: Kozan-ji Temple's honorific mountain prefix is 'Tsuganoosan' and it belongs to the Omuro branch of the Shingon Sect.
Kozan-ji Temple's honorific mountain prefix is 'Toganoosan' and it belongs to the Omuro branch of the Shingon Sect.
sen.cmt: Tsuganoosan→Toganoosan巣立→単立寺院の事でしょうか？英訳には反映されていません。
sen.e: Kozan-ji Temple's sango (literally, "mountain name"), which is the title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple, is 'Toganoosan' and it originates from the Omuro school of the Shingon Sect.
sen.cmt: honorific mountain prefix→sango (literally, "mountain name"), which is the title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple～派用語統一巣立は、真言宗御室派系からの派生として訳しました。

sen.j: 創建は奈良時代と伝えるが、実質的な開基（創立者）は、鎌倉時代の明恵である。
sen.e: It is said to have been founded in the Nara period, but the actual Kaiki (patron of a temple in its founding) was Kamakura period monk Myoe.
sen.cmt: ・Kaiki (patron of a temple in its founding): 新和英大辞典
sen.e: It is said to have been founded in the Nara period, but the actual Kaiki (patron of a temple in its founding) was Kamakura period monk Myoe.
It is said to have been founded in the Nara period, but the actual Kaiki (patron of a temple in its founding) was Kamakura period monk Myoe.

sen.j: 「鳥獣人物戯画」をはじめ、絵画、典籍、文書など、多くの文化財を伝える寺院として知られる。
sen.e: In addition to 'Choju-Jinbutsu-Giga' (Scrolls of Frolicking Animals and Humans), the temple is renowned for its numerous cultural properties including paintings, ancient writings and documents.
In addition to 'Choju-Jinbutsu-Giga' (Scrolls of Frolicking Animals and Humans), the temple is renowned for its numerous cultural properties including paintings, ancient writings and documents.
In addition to 'Choju-Jinbutsu-Giga' (Scrolls of Frolicking Animals and Humans), the temple is renowned for its numerous cultural properties including paintings, ancient writings and documents.

sen.j: 境内が国の史跡に指定されており、また古都京都の文化財の一部として世界遺産に登録されている。
sen.e: The temple precinct has been designated both a national historic site and a UNESCO World Heritage Site as one of the 'Historic Monuments of Ancient Kyoto.
The temple precinct has been designated both a national historic site and a UNESCO World Heritage Site as one of the 'Historic Monuments of Ancient Kyoto.'
The temple precinct has been designated both a national historic site and a UNESCO World Heritage Site as one of the Historic Monuments of Ancient Kyoto.

sen.j: 高山寺のある栂尾は、紅葉の名所として知られる高雄山神護寺からさらに奥に入った山中に位置し、古代より山岳修行の適地として、小寺院が営まれていたようである。
sen.e: The Toganoo area in which Kozan-ji Temple is located is even deeper in the mountains than Takaosan Jingo-ji Temple - known for its red autumn leaves, has long been a place of mountain asceticism and is thought to have once been the site of many small temples.
sen.cmt: ・mountain ascetic practices: 新和英大辞典
sen.e: The Toganoo area in which Kozan-ji Temple is located is even deeper in the mountains than Takaosan Jingo-ji Temple - known for its red autumn leaves, has long been a place of mountain asceticism and is thought to have once been the site of many small temples.

The Toganoo area in which Kozan-ji Temple is located is even deeper in the mountains than Takaosan Jingo-ji Temple - known for its red autumn leaves, has long been a place of mountain asceticism and is thought to have once been the site of many small temples.

sen.j: 今の高山寺の地には、奈良時代から「度賀尾寺」「都賀尾坊」などと称される寺院があり、宝亀5年（774年）、光仁天皇の勅願で建立されたとの伝えもあるが、当時の実態は明らかでない。
sen.e: Since the Nara period, the current site of Kozan-ji Temple has been home to temples including 'Togao-ji' and 'Togao-bo', and it is said that it was constructed in the year 774 by the imperial decree of Emperor Konin, but the accuracy of these claims remains unclear.

Since the Nara period, the current site of Kozan-ji Temple has been home to temples including 'Togao-ji' and 'Togao-bo', and it is said that it was constructed in the year 774 by the imperial decree of Emperor Konin, but the accuracy of these claims remains unclear.

Since the Nara period, the current site of Kozan-ji Temple has been home to temples including 'Togao-ji' and 'Togao-bo,' and it is said that it was constructed in the year 774 by the imperial decree of Emperor Konin, but the accuracy of these claims remains unclear.

sen.j: 平安時代には、近隣の神護寺の別院とされ、神護寺十無尽院（じゅうむじんいん）と称されていた。
sen.e: In the Heian period, the temple became a branch temple of the nearby Jingo-ji Temple and became known as Jingo-ji Jumujinin Temple.
sen.cmt: ・branch temple: 英辞郎 on the WEB
sen.e: In the Heian period, the temple became a branch temple of the nearby Jingo-ji Temple and became known as Jingo-ji Jumujinin Temple.
In the Heian period, the temple became a branch temple of the nearby Jingo-ji Temple and became known as Jingo-ji Jumujinin Temple.

sen.j: これは、神護寺本寺から離れた、隠棲修行の場所であったらしい。
sen.e: It is then thought to have separated from Jingo-ji Temple and served as a place of secluded asceticism.
It is then thought to have separated from a head temple, Jingo-ji Temple and served as a place of secluded asceticism.
It is then thought to have separated from a head temple, Jingo-ji Temple and served as a place of secluded asceticism.

sen.j: 高山寺の中興の祖であり、実質的な開基とされるのは、鎌倉時代の華厳宗の僧、明恵（みょうえ）である。
sen.e: The individual responsible for restoring Kozan-ji Temple and considered to be the official Kaiki (patron of a temple in its founding) is Kamakura period Kegon Sect monk Myoe.
sen.cmt: ・Kaiki (patron of a temple in its founding): 新和英大辞典・Kegon sect: 新和英大辞典
sen.e: The individual responsible for restoring Kozan-ji Temple and considered to be the official Kaiki (patron of a temple in its founding) is Kamakura period Kegon Sect monk Myoe.
The individual responsible for restoring Kozan-ji Temple and considered to be the official Kaiki (patron of a temple in its founding) is Kamakura period Kegon Sect monk Myoe.

sen.j: 明恵房高弁（1173－1232）は承安 (日本)3年（1173年）、紀伊国有田郡は現在の和歌山県有田川町にあたる場所で生まれた。
sen.e: Myoe-bo Koben (1173-1232) was born in the Arida District of Kii Province, which is equivalent to modern day Aritagawa-Cho in Wakayama Prefecture.
Myoe-bo Koben (1173-1232) was born in the Arida District of Kii Province, which is equivalent to modern day Aridagawa-Cho in Wakayama Prefecture in 1173.
Myoe-bo Koben (1173-1232) was born in the Arida District of Kii Province, which is equivalent to modern day Aridagawa-Cho in Wakayama Prefecture in 1173.

sen.j: 父は平重国という武士であり、母は紀州の豪族湯浅家の娘であった。
sen.e: His father was a warrior named TAIRA no Shigekuni and his mother was of the powerful Kii Province Yuasa family.
His father was a warrior named TAIRA no Shigekuni and his mother was of the powerful Kii Province Yuasa family.
His father was a warrior named TAIRA no Shigekuni and his mother was a daughter of the powerful Kii Province Yuasa family.

sen.j: 幼時に両親を亡くした明恵は、9歳で生家を離れ、母方の叔父に当たる神護寺の僧・上覚（1147－1226）のもとで仏門に入った。
sen.e: After the death of his parents, Myoe left home aged 9 and entered the Buddhist priesthood under the guidance of his maternal uncle, the monk Jokaku of Jingo-ji Temple.
After the death of his parents, Myoe left home aged 9 and entered the Buddhist priesthood under the guidance of his maternal uncle, the monk Jokaku of Jingo-ji Temple.
After the death of his parents, Myoe left home aged 9 and entered the Buddhist priesthood under the guidance of his maternal uncle, the monk Jokaku (1147－1226) of Jingo-ji Temple.

sen.j: 明恵は、法然の唱えた「専修念仏」の思想を痛烈に批判し、華厳宗の復興に努めた。
sen.e: Myoe was severely critical of Honen's exclusive nembutsu practice and strived toward the revival of the Kegon Sect.
Myoe was severely critical of Honen's exclusive nembutsu practice and strived toward the revival of the Kegon Sect.
Myoe was severely critical of Honen's exclusive nenbutsu practice and strived toward the revival of the Kegon Sect.

sen.j: 「専修念仏」とは、仏法が衰えた「末法」の時代には、人は菩提心（さとり）によって救われることはなく、念仏以外の方法で極楽往生することはできないという主張であり、これは菩提心や戒律を重視する明恵の思想とは相反するものであった。
sen.e: In an age of decadence in which Buddhism's standing was weakening, the teachings of exclusive nembutsu that people are not saved by the aspiration for Buddhahood and that, with the exception of nembutsu, there is no other method of being reborn in paradise were in contradiction to the beliefs Myoe who emphasized discipline and the attainment of enlightenment

In an 'age of decadence' in which Buddhism's standing was weakening, the teachings of 'exclusive nembutsu' that people are not saved by the aspiration for Buddhahood and that, with the exception of nembutsu, there is no other method of being reborn in paradise were in contradiction to the beliefs Myoe who emphasized discipline and the attainment of enlightenment.
sen.cmt: Buddhism’s→Buddhism's原文の「」→ '' としました。ピリオドを補足。
sen.e: In an 'age of decadence' in which Buddhism's standing was weakening, the teachings of 'exclusive nenbutsu' that people are not saved by the aspiration for Buddhahood and that, with the exception of nenbutsu, there is no other method of being reborn in paradise were in contradiction to the beliefs Myoe who emphasized discipline and the attainment of enlightenment.

sen.j: 明恵は建永元年（1206年）、34歳の時に後鳥羽天皇から栂尾の地を与えられ、また寺名のもとになった「日出先照高山之寺」の額を下賜された。
sen.e: In the year 1206 aged 34, Myoe was granted land at Toganoo by Emperor Go-Toba who also conferred upon the temple the name 'Hi-idete-mazu-terasu-Kozan-no -tera' (First Mountain Temple Illuminated by the Rising Sun).

In the year 1206 aged 34, Myoe was granted land at Toganoo by Emperor Go-Toba who also conferred upon the temple the name 'Hi-idete-mazu-terasu-Kozan-no-tera' (First Mountain Temple Illuminated by the Rising Sun).

In the year 1206 aged 34, Myoe was granted land at Toganoo by Emperor Gotoba who also conferred upon the temple the name 'Hi-idete-mazu-terasu-Kozan-no-tera' (First Mountain Temple Illuminated by the Rising Sun).

sen.j: この時が現・高山寺の創立と見なされている。
sen.e: This is considered to be the founding of the current Kozan-ji Temple.
This is considered to be the founding of the current Kozan-ji Temple.
This is considered to be the founding of the current Kozan-ji Temple.

sen.j: 「日出先照高山」（日、出でて、まず高き山を照らす）とは、「華厳経」の中の句で、「朝日が昇って、真っ先に照らされるのは高い山の頂上だ」という意味であり、そのように光り輝く寺院であれとの意が込められていると思われる。
sen.e: The temple's name was taken from a line in the Avatamsaka sutra which states 'Hi, idete, mazu takaki yama wo terasu' which means 'When the sun rises, it first casts its light upon the highest mountain', and is believed to have been chosen in the hope that the temple would be illuminated as described in the passage.

The temple's name was taken from a line in the 'Avatamsaka sutra' which states 'Hi, idete, mazu takaki yama wo terasu' which means 'When the sun rises, it first casts its light upon the highest mountain', and is believed to have been chosen in the hope that the temple would be illuminated as described in the passage.
sen.cmt: 原文にあるので「」→ 'Avatamsaka sutra' としました。
sen.e: The temple's name was taken from a line in the 'Avatamsaka sutra' which states 'Hi, idete, mazu takaki yama wo terasu' which means 'When the sun rises, it first casts its light upon the highest mountain,' and is believed to have been chosen in the hope that the temple would be illuminated as described in the passage.

sen.j: 高山寺は中世以降、たびたびの戦乱や火災で焼失し、鎌倉時代の建物は石水院を残すのみとなっている。
sen.e: Since the medieval period, Kozan-ji Temple has been destroyed numerous times by conflict and fire and the only Kamakura period building to survive is Sekisui-in.
sen.cmt: ・medieval period: 新和英大辞典・Sekisui-in: http://kaiwai.city.kyoto.jp/search/menu_small.php
sen.e: Since the medieval period, Kozan-ji Temple has been destroyed numerous times by conflict and fire and the only Kamakura period building to survive is Sekisui-in.
Since the medieval period, Kozan-ji Temple has been destroyed numerous times by conflict and fire and the only Kamakura period building to survive is Sekisui-in.

sen.j: 建永元年の中興から20数年を経た寛喜2年（1230年）に作成された高山寺境内の絵図（重文、神護寺蔵）が現存しており、当時の様子が具体的にわかる点で貴重である。
sen.e: A surviving diagram of the Kozan-ji Temple precinct (Important Cultural Property, housed at Jigo-ji Temple) was created in 1230, over 20 years after its 1206 revival, and has been extremely valuable in verifying the layout of the temple at the time.

A surviving diagram of the Kozan-ji Temple precinct (Important Cultural Property, housed at Jingo-ji Temple) was created in 1230, over 20 years after its 1206 revival, and has been extremely valuable in verifying the layout of the temple at the time.

A surviving diagram of the Kozan-ji Temple precinct (Important Cultural Property, housed at Jingo-ji Temple) was created in 1230, over 20 years after its 1206 revival, and has been extremely valuable in verifying the layout of the temple at the time.

sen.j: それによると、当時の高山寺には、大門、金堂、三重塔、阿弥陀堂、羅漢堂、鐘楼、経蔵、鎮守社などがあったことが知られるが、このうち、当時「経蔵」と呼ばれた建物が「石水院」として現存するほかは、ことごとく失われている。
sen.e: From the diagram, we know that Kozan-ji originally consisted of a large outer gate, a main hall, a three-storied pagoda, an Amitabha hall, an Arhat hall, a bell tower, a scripture hall, and a Shinto shrine dedicated to the tutelary deity of the area, but all of these buildings have since been destroyed with he exception of the scripture hall, which is now known as 'Sekisui-in'.
sen.cmt: ・a three-storied pagoda: 新和英大辞典・an Amitabha hall: 新和英大辞典・bell tower: 英辞郎 on the WEB・Sekisui-in: http://kaiwai.city.kyoto.jp/search/menu_small.php
sen.e: From the diagram, we know that Kozan-ji Temple originally consisted of a large outer gate, a main hall, a three-storied pagoda, an Amitabha hall, an Arhat hall, a bell tower, a scripture hall, and a Shinto shrine dedicated to the tutelary deity of the area, but all of these buildings have since been destroyed with he exception of the 'scripture hall,' which is now known as 'Sekisui-in'.
sen.cmt: Kozan-ji→Kozan-ji Temple原文にあるので「」→ '' としましたが、必要無ければ省略して下さい。
sen.e: From the diagram, we know that Kozan-ji Temple originally consisted of a large outer gate, a main hall, a three-storied pagoda, an Amitabha hall, an Arhat hall, a bell tower, a scripture hall, and a Shinto shrine dedicated to the tutelary deity of the area, but all of these buildings have since been destroyed with he exception of the 'scripture hall,' which is now known as 'Sekisui-in.'

sen.j: 石水院から開山堂に至る道の両側に残る石垣は、かつての諸堂や塔頭を偲ばせている。
sen.e: The stone walls lining both sides of the path that leads from Sekisui-in to Kaizan-do is reminiscent of the halls and sub-temples that once stood on the site.
The stone walls lining both sides of the path that leads from Sekisui-in to Kaizan-do is reminiscent of the halls and sub-temples that once stood on the site.
The stone walls lining both sides of the path that leads from Sekisui-in to Kaizan-do (it is also pronounced Kaisan-do) is reminiscent of the halls and sub-temples that once stood on the site.

sen.j: 石水院（国宝）－鎌倉時代の建築。
sen.e: Sekisui-in (National Treasure): Constructed in the Kamakura Period.
Sekisui-in (National Treasure): Constructed in the Kamakura Period.
Sekisui-in (National Treasure): Constructed in the Kamakura period.

sen.j: 入母屋造、杮（こけら）葺き。
sen.e: Topped by a hip-and-gable shingle roof.
Topped by a hip-and-gable shingle roof.
Topped by a hip-and-gable shingle roof.

sen.j: 後鳥羽上皇の学問所を下賜されたものと伝え、明恵の住房跡とも伝える。
sen.e: Said to have once been the place of study of retired Emperor Go-Toba and bestowed to the temple, but others claim it to be the remains of Myoe's dwelling.
Said to have once been the place of study of retired Emperor Go-Toba and bestowed to the temple, but others claim it to be the remains of Myoe's dwelling.
Said to have once been the place of study of Retired Emperor Gotoba and bestowed to the temple, but others claim it to be the remains of Myoe's dwelling.

sen.j: 外観は住宅風だが、本来は経蔵として造られた建物を改造したものと見られる。
sen.e: The exterior is in a residential style, but it appears to have been converted from a structure which originally served as a sutra hall.
The exterior is in a residential style, but it appears to have been converted from a structure which originally served as a sutra hall.
The exterior is in a residential style, but it appears to have been converted from a structure which originally served as a sutra hall.

sen.j: もともとは金堂の右後方に残る石段の上に建っていたが、明治22年(1889年)に現在地に移築したものである。
sen.e: It was originally located atop the stone staircase that remains to the back right of the main hall, but was relocated to its current position in 1889.
It was originally located atop the stone staircase that remains to the back right of the main hall, but was relocated to its current position in 1889.
It was originally located atop the stone staircase that remains to the back right of the main hall, but was relocated to its current position in 1889.

sen.j: 他に、仁和寺から移築した金堂、明恵の肖像彫刻（重文）を安置する開山堂などがあるが、いずれも近世の建築である。
sen.e: Additionally, today's Kozan-ji also contains a main hall that was relocated from Ninna-ji Temple and a Kaizan-do which houses a wooden statue of Myo, but both are modern reconstructions.

Additionally, today's Kozan-ji Temple also contains a main hall that was relocated from Ninna-ji Temple and a Kaizan-do which houses a wooden statue of Myoe (Important Cultural Property), but both are modern reconstructions.

Additionally, today's Kozan-ji Temple also contains a main hall that was relocated from Ninna-ji Temple and a Kaizan-do which houses a wooden statue of Myoe (Important Cultural Property), but both are modern reconstructions.

sen.j: 境内には「日本最古」と伝える茶園がある。
sen.e: The grounds are also home to a tea garden said to be the oldest in Japan.
The grounds are also home to a tea garden said to be the oldest in Japan.
The grounds are also home to a tea garden said to be the oldest in Japan.

sen.j: 鎌倉時代初期に臨済宗の開祖栄西が、当時の中国の南宋において種を得て、帰国後に明恵に贈ったものと伝える。
sen.e: The story claims that the varieties of tea were obtained by Rinzai Sect founder Eisai in Southern Song period China and granted to the temple following his return to Japan.
The story claims that the varieties of tea were obtained by Rinzai Sect founder Eisai in Southern Song period China in the early Kamakura period and granted to Myoe following his return to Japan.
sen.cmt: 鎌倉時代初期に→in the early Kamakura period 明恵に→to Myoe
sen.e: The story claims that the varieties of tea were obtained by Rinzai Sect founder Eisai in Southern Song period China in the early Kamakura period and granted to Myoe following his return to Japan.

sen.j: 明恵はこれを初めは栂尾山に植え、その後宇治その他の土地に広まったという。
sen.e: It is also said that Myoe planted these on Mt. Tsuganoo-san from where they spread to other areas including Uji.
It is also said that Myoe planted these on Mt. Toganoo-san from where they spread to other areas including Uji.
It is also said that Myoe planted these on Mt. Toganoo from where they spread to other areas including Uji.

sen.j: 数多くの文化財を所蔵するが、建造物を除く指定文化財の大部分は東京および京都の国立博物館に寄託されている。
sen.e: The temple possesses numerous cultural properties, but the majority of them have been deposited at the national museums in Tokyo and Kyoto.
The temple possesses numerous cultural properties, but the majority of them except buildings have been deposited at the national museums in Tokyo and Kyoto.

sen.j: 石水院
sen.e: Sekisui-in
Sekisui-in

sen.j: 紙本墨画鳥獣人物戯画 4巻 － 甲乙丙丁の4巻からなる絵巻。
sen.e: Ink on paper 'Choju-Jinbutsu-Giga' (Scrolls of Frolicking Animals and Humans): A set of four picture scrolls.
Ink on paper 'Choju-Jinbutsu-Giga' (Scrolls of Frolicking Animals and Humans): A set of four picture scrolls.
Monochrome ink painting on paper 'Choju-Jinbutsu-Giga' (Scrolls of Frolicking Animals and Humans): A set of four picture scrolls.

sen.j: すべて墨画で彩色はない。
sen.e: They are all done in India-ink with no use of color.
They are all done in India-ink with no use of color.
They are all done in monochrome ink with no use of color.

sen.j: また、普通の絵巻のように絵と詞（ことば）が交互に現われる形式ではなく、絵のみで構成される。
sen.e: Unlike ordinary picture scrolls which include images and writing, they consist of pictures only.
Unlike ordinary picture scrolls which include images and writing, they consist of pictures only.
Unlike ordinary picture scrolls which include images and writing, they consist of pictures only.

sen.j: 甲巻は兎、蛙、猿などの動物を擬人化したもので、4巻の中でもっともよく知られる。
sen.e: The first scroll depicts anthropomorphosized rabbits, frogs and monkeys and is the best known of the four scrolls.
The first scroll depicts anthropomorphosized rabbits, frogs and monkeys and is the best known of the four scrolls.
The first scroll depicts anthropomorphosized rabbits, frogs and monkeys and is the best known of the four scrolls.

sen.j: 乙巻は写生風の動物絵、丙巻は前半が各種の競技やゲームに興じる人物の戯画で、後半は動物戯画、丁巻は荒々しいタッチの人物戯画である。
sen.e: The second scroll illustrates sketches of animals, the third depicts caricatures of people engaging in a variety of competitions and games in the first half with animal caricatures in the second half, and the fourth consists of rough human caricatures.

The second scroll illustrates sketches of animals, the third depicts caricatures of people engaging in a variety of competitions and games in the first half with animal caricatures in the second half, and the fourth consists of rough human caricatures.

The second scroll illustrates sketches of animals, the third depicts caricatures of people engaging in a variety of competitions and games in the first half with animal caricatures in the second half, and the fourth consists of rough human caricatures.

sen.j: 制作年代は甲・乙巻が平安末期、丙・丁巻は鎌倉時代と推定される。
sen.e: It is estimated that the first and second volumes were created during the late Heian period and the third and fourth volumes during the Kamakura period.
It is estimated that the first and second volumes were created during the late Heian period and the third and fourth volumes during the Kamakura period.
It is estimated that the first and second volumes were created during the late Heian period and the third and fourth volumes during the Kamakura period.

sen.j: 制作事情、主題等については諸説あるが、特に甲巻のユーモラスな動物戯画は秀逸で、現代日本の漫画文化のルーツとも見なされる。
sen.e: There are numerous theories regarding the circumstances of their creation, but the humorous animal caricatures of the first volume are particularly outstanding and considered to be the origin of modern Japanese Manga culture.

There are numerous theories regarding the circumstances of their creation and themes, but the humorous animal caricatures of the first volume are particularly outstanding and considered to be the origin of modern Japanese Manga culture.

There are numerous theories regarding the circumstances of their creation and themes, but the humorous animal caricatures of the first volume are particularly outstanding and considered to be the origin of modern Japanese Manga culture.

sen.j: 現在は甲・丙巻が東京国立博物館、乙・丁巻が京都国立博物館に寄託されているため寺で見られるのは模本である。
sen.e: Those on display at the temple are copies, as volumes 1 and 2 are currently deposited at Tokyo National Museum and volumes 3 and 4 are deposited at Kyoto National Museum.
sen.cmt: ・Tokyo National Museum: http://www.tnm.jp/jp/guide/index.html・Kyoto National Museum: http://www.kyohaku.go.jp/

sen.e: Kegon-shu Soshi Eden 7-kan (seven scrolls of pictorial biographies of the founders of the Kegon Sect): Created during the Kamakura period.

sen.j: 新羅の華厳宗の祖とされる義湘と元暁の伝記絵巻である。
sen.e: Portrays the lives of Silla Kingdom Kegon founders Uisang and Wonhyo.
Portrays the lives of Silla Kingdom Kegon founders Uisang and Wonhyo.
Portrays the lives of Silla Kingdom Kegon Sect founders Uisang and Wonhyo.

sen.j: 国宝指定時は全6巻であったが、修理後は7巻に調巻されている。
sen.e: Consisted of 6 scrolls when designated a National Treasure, but rearranged into 7 scrolls after undergoing repairs.
Consisted of 6 scrolls when designated a National Treasure, but rearranged into 7 scrolls after undergoing repairs.
Consisted of 6 scrolls when designated a National Treasure, but rearranged into 7 scrolls after undergoing repairs.

sen.j: 紙本著色明恵上人像（絵画）－「樹上座禅像」と称される。
sen.e: Color on paper Myoe Shonin-zo (portrait of the monk Myoe: Also known as 'Jujo Zazen zo' (Zen Meditation in a Tree).
Color on paper Myoe Shonin-zo (portrait of the monk Myoe: Also known as 'Jujo Zazen zo' (Zen Meditation in a Tree).

sen.j: 通例の祖師像と異なり、明恵の姿は山中の自然景の中に小さく表現されている。
sen.e: In contrast to the standard image of a Buddhist monk, this picture depicts a tiny Myoe surrounded by a mountain landscape.
In contrast to the standard image of a Buddhist monk, this picture depicts a tiny Myoe surrounded by a mountain landscape.
In contrast to the standard image of a Buddhist monk, this picture depicts a tiny Myoe surrounded by a mountain landscape.

sen.j: 鎌倉時代の作。
sen.e: It was created during the Kamakura period.
It was created during the Kamakura period.
It was created during the Kamakura period.

sen.j: 絹本著色仏眼仏母像（絵画）－ 鎌倉時代初期、12世紀末の作。
sen.e: Color on silk Butsugen-Butsumo-zo (painting): Created in the Kamakura Period at the end of the 12th century.
Color on silk Butsugen-Butsumo-zo (painting): Created in the early Kamakura Period at the end of the 12th century.

sen.j: 明恵の念持仏であり、図中には明恵自身による書き込みがある。
sen.e: This image was personally owned by Myoe and contains his own writing.
This image was personally owned by Myoe and contains his own writing.

sen.j: 玉篇（ぎょくへん）巻第廿七 － 中国梁代成立の漢字辞書「玉篇」の、唐時代の写本。
sen.e: Yupian Volume 27: A Tang Dynasty copy of a Chinese character dictionary 'Yupian' created during the Liang Dynasty.
Yupian Volume 27: A Tang Dynasty copy of a Chinese character dictionary 'Yupian' created during the Liang Dynasty.
Yupian Volume 27: A Tang Dynasty copy of a Chinese character dictionary 'Yupian' created during the Liang Dynasty.

sen.j: 本書の写本は中国では早くに失われて日本にしか残っていない点で貴重。
sen.e: It is incredibly valuable as all copies of the text have long disappeared from China with this last remaining copy only surviving in Japan.
It is incredibly valuable as all copies of the text have long disappeared from China with this last remaining copy only surviving in Japan.
It is incredibly valuable as all copies of the text have long disappeared from China with this last remaining copy only surviving in Japan.

sen.j: 篆隷万象名義（てんれいばんしょうめいぎ）－ 空海の編さんとされる漢字辞書の唯一の古写本として貴重。
sen.e: Tenrei Bansho Meigi: Valued as the only remaining copy of a Chinese character dictionary believed to have been compiled by Kukai.
Tenrei Bansho Meigi: Valued as the only remaining copy of a Chinese character dictionary believed to have been compiled by Kukai.
Tenrei Bansho Meigi: Valued as the only remaining copy of a Chinese character dictionary believed to have been compiled by Kukai.

sen.j: 永久2年（1114年）の写本。
sen.e: It was copied in 1114
It was copied in 1114.

sen.j: 冥報記（めいほうき） － 唐代成立の仏教説話集の写本で、成立から2世紀ほど後の唐代末期の写本とされる。
sen.e: Ming Bao Ji: This copy of a Tang Dynasty collection of Buddhist tales is believed to have been transcribed in the late Tang Dynasty, 2 decades after being first written.
sen.cmt: ・collection of Buddhist tales: アドバンストフェイバリット和英辞典
sen.e: Ming Bao Ji: This copy of a Tang Dynasty collection of Buddhist tales is believed to have been transcribed in the late Tang Dynasty, 2 centuries after being first written.

sen.j: 本書は中国では早くに失われており、現存最古写本として貴重。
sen.e: It is incredibly valuable as all copies have long disappeared from China with this being the oldest copy in existence.

sen.j: 乾漆薬師如来坐像－奈良時代末期の作。
sen.e: Lacquered wooden sitting statue of Bhaisajyaguru: Created towards the end of the Nara period
Dry lacquered wooden sitting statue of Bhaisajyaguru: Created towards the end of the Nara period.
sen.cmt: Dryを補足。ピリオドを補足。
sen.e: Dry lacquered wooden seated statue of Bhaisajyaguru: Created towards the end of the Nara period.

sen.j: 元来は薬師三尊像の中尊であった。
sen.e: It was originally the center of a trio of Buddhist statues flanked by two attendants.
It was originally the center of a trio of Buddhist statues flanked by two attendants.
It was originally the center of a trio of Buddhist statues flanked by two attendants.

sen.j: 両脇侍像は明治時代に寺外に流出し、日光菩薩像は東京国立博物館、月光（がっこう）菩薩像は東京藝術大学大学美術館に所蔵されている。
sen.e: The attendants were removed from the temple during the Meiji period, with the statue of Suryaprabha now at the Tokyo National Museum and the statue of Chandraprabha at the university museum of the Tokyo National University of Fine Arts and Music.

The attendants were removed from the temple during the Meiji period, with the statue of Suryaprabha now at the Tokyo National Museum and the statue of Chandraprabha at the university museum of the Tokyo National University of Fine Arts and Music.

sen.j: 木造明恵上人坐像－開山堂に安置。
sen.e: Wooden sitting statue of Monk Myoe: Housed within the Kaizan-do.
Wooden sitting statue of Monk Myoe: Housed within the Kaizan-do.

sen.j: 鎌倉時代の作。
sen.e: Created during the Kamakura period.
Created during the Kamakura period.

sen.j: 木造鹿1対－鎌倉時代。
sen.e: A pair of wooden deer statues: Created during the Kamakura period.
A pair of wooden deer statues: Created during the Kamakura period.
A pair of wooden deer statues: Created during the Kamakura period.

sen.j: 雌雄の鹿を狛犬風に作ったもので、他に例を見ない。
sen.e: These unique statues of a buck and doe have been crafted to resemble the lion-dog statues that stand guard at the entrances to Shinto shrines.
These unique statues of a buck and doe have been crafted to resemble the lion-dog statues that stand guard at the entrances to Shinto shrines.
These unique statues of a buck and doe have been crafted to resemble the lion-dog statues that stand guard at the entrances to Shinto shrines.

sen.j: 鹿は春日明神の使いとされ、高山寺鎮守の春日明神の神前に置かれたものと思われる。
sen.e: Deer are messengers of Kasuga-Myojin and it is believed that these statues were placed in front of the Kasuga Myojin shrine that once stood within Kozan-ji Temple.
Deer are messengers of Kasuga-Myojin and it is believed that these statues were placed in front of the Kasuga Myojin shrine that once stood within Kozan-ji Temple.
Deer are messengers of Kasuga-Myojin and it is believed that these statues were placed in front of the Kasuga Myojin shrine that once stood within Kozan-ji Temple.

sen.j: 木造白光神（びゃっこうしん）立像－鎌倉時代初期。
sen.e: Wooden standing statue of Byakkoshin: Created in the early Kamakura period.
Wooden standing statue of Byakkoshin: Created in the early Kamakura period.
Wooden standing statue of Byakkoshin: Created in the early Kamakura period.

sen.j: 白光神は、インドの神とされ、善妙神（中国の神）、春日明神（日本の神）とともに高山寺の鎮守神として祭られた。
sen.e: Byakkoshin is thought to be an Indian God that was enshrined within the Kozan-ji Temple shrine along with Zenmyoshin (Chinese God) and Kasuga-Myojin (Japanese God).
Byakkoshin is thought to be an Indian God that was enshrined within the Kozan-ji Temple shrine along with Zemmyoshin (Chinese God) and Kasuga-Myojin (Japanese God).
Byakkoshin is thought to be an Indian God that was enshrined within the Kozan-ji Temple shrine along with Zenmyoshin (Chinese God) and Kasuga-Myojin (Japanese God).

sen.j: 名前の通り、着衣から台座まで真っ白に塗られているが、これはヒマラヤの雪を象徴するものという。
sen.e: As the name Byakoushin (lit. White Light God) indicates, the statue is painted entirely in white from its clothing to the pedestal, which is said to represent the snow of the Himalayas.
As the name Byakkoshin (lit. White Light God) indicates, the statue is painted entirely in white from its clothing to the pedestal, which is said to represent the snow of the Himalayas.
As the name Byakkoshin (lit. White Light God) indicates, the statue is painted entirely in white from its clothing to the pedestal, which is said to represent the snow of the Himalayas.

sen.j: 木造善妙神立像－鎌倉時代初期。
sen.e: Wooden standing statue of Zenmyoshin: Created in the early Kamakura period.
Wooden standing statue of Zemmyoshin: Created in the early Kamakura period.
Wooden standing statue of Zenmyoshin: Created in the early Kamakura period.

sen.j: 鮮やかな彩色がよく残る。
sen.e: Much of the vivid paint still remains.
Much of the vivid paint still remains.
Much of the vivid paint still remains.

sen.j: 白光神像とともに、仏師湛慶の作と推定されている。
sen.e: It is said to be the work of Buddhist sculptor Tankei along with the statue of Byakkoshin.
It is said to be the work of Buddhist sculptor Tankei along with the statue of Byakkoshin.
It is said to be the work of Buddhist sculptor Tankei along with the statue of Byakkoshin.

sen.j: 高山寺典籍文書（もんじょ）類9,293点－高山寺に伝来する平安時代から近世に至る仏典、記録等を一括指定したもの。
sen.e: The Kozan-ji Temple Archive containing 9,293 items: Incorporates all documents including Buddhist texts and records which have been stored at Kozan-ji Temple from the Heian period to modern times.

sen.j: 高弁夢記（こうべんゆめのき）17点－「高弁」は明恵のこと。
sen.e: 17 volumes of Koben Yume-no-Ki: 'Koben' refers to Myoe.
17 volumes of Koben Yume-no-Ki: 'Koben' refers to Myoe.
17 volumes of Koben Yume-no-Ki: 'Koben' refers to Myoe.

sen.j: 明恵が自分の見た夢を記録した日記であり、夢の中での宗教的経験が彼の思想に大きく影響していることがわかる。
sen.e: A record that Myoe kept of his dreams, the religious experiences of which are said to have greatly influenced his way of thinking.
A record that Myoe kept of his dreams, the religious experiences of which are said to have greatly influenced his way of thinking.
A record that Myoe kept of his dreams, the religious experiences of which are said to have greatly influenced his way of thinking.

sen.j: 建久7年（1196年、23歳）から貞応2年（1223年、51歳）までのものが残っている。
